image.altText: A young woman is on the shoulders of a man in a march. She's holding an Aboriginal flag

items.synopsis: Thousands take to the streets of Darwin CBD for a NAIDOC parade that sees renewed calls for a treaty between First Nations people and the federal government, and calls for a Yes vote for an Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

title.children: 'Only way to make our mob stronger': Leaders champion Yes vote at NAIDOC march

image.altText: Commissioner Catherine Holmes, ex pm Scott Morrison, ex ministers Alan Tudge and Stuart Robert, bureaucrat Kathryn Campbell

items.synopsis: The political recriminations for findings of the Robodebt royal commission have been swift, with the prime minister dubbing the former debt collecting mechanism a "gross betrayal" of the Australian people. So what did the commission find about those who oversaw the scheme?

title.children: What did the Robodebt royal commission find about the people who oversaw the scheme?

image.altText: Pat Cummins smiles and high-fives Mitch Marsh

items.synopsis: Pat Cummins completes a five-wicket-haul just after lunch to put Australia in the box seat on day two of the third Ashes Test at Headingley. Follow all the updates in our live blog.

title.children: Cummins takes five wickets as Australia looks to skittle England on day two at Headingley

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Well, it was fun while it lasted, I guess. Wood gets a top edge, sends it into orbit and Mitch Marsh takes a towering catch. A relief, I guess for Australia, but their tactics are highly questionable. That's five wickets for Cummins.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: OUT! WOOD SKIES ONE!

children.content: Well, it was fun while it lasted, I guess.
Wood gets a top edge, sends it into orbit and Mitch Marsh takes a towering catch.
A relief, I guess for Australia, but their tactics are highly questionable.
That's five wickets for Cummins.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ben Stokes is still out in the middle on 27 and is building into his innings nicely, but he's running out of partners. England, remarkably, are still 121 runs behind Australia with just three wickets left in this first innings. Stokes has form at Headingley and will have to draw on all of it to get his side a first-innings lead here. Mark Wood, Ollie Robinson and Stuart Broad are in next and Stokes will be eager to give them absolutely no strike after lunch to give England a chance.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chris Woakes falls on the stroke of lunch, with England 7-142

props.alt: England batter Ben Stokes on his knees behind Australia bowler Mitchell Starc.

children.content: (Getty)
Ben Stokes is still out in the middle on 27 and is building into his innings nicely, but he's running out of partners.

England, remarkably, are still 121 runs behind Australia with just three wickets left in this first innings. Stokes has form at Headingley and will have to draw on all of it to get his side a first-innings lead here.
Mark Wood, Ollie Robinson and Stuart Broad are in next and Stokes will be eager to give them absolutely no strike after lunch to give England a chance.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I have no idea what sort of shot that was from Bairstow, he's flashed at a very wide one and he edges it to Steve Smith at second slip! Bairstow is out for 12! It's a truly appalling shot and has left England in the mire, 5-87, trailing by 176. "Poor shot from Bairstow," says Sir Alastair Cook on BBC Radio. "He lost his shape and it's another good catch from Australia. "Root and Bairstow were key." It's Steve Smith's 51st Ashes catch, the second most ever shared with Allan Border. Only Ian Botham has taken more with 54. It's the 10th time that Mitchell Starc has dismissed Jonny Bairstow - not quite Broad to Warner territory, but well up there.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EDGED! TAKEN! STARC HAS BAIRSTOW!

children.content: I have no idea what sort of shot that was from Bairstow, he's flashed at a very wide one and he edges it to Steve Smith at second slip!
(Getty Images)
Bairstow is out for 12!
(Getty Images)
It's a truly appalling shot and has left England in the mire, 5-87, trailing by 176.
"Poor shot from Bairstow," says
Sir Alastair Cook on BBC Radio.
"He lost his shape and it's another good catch from Australia.
"Root and Bairstow were key."
It's Steve Smith's 51st Ashes catch, the second most ever shared with Allan Border.
Only Ian Botham has taken more with 54.
It's the 10th time that Mitchell Starc has dismissed Jonny Bairstow - not quite Broad to Warner territory, but well up there.

image.altText: A shimmering yellow sun sinks behind a row of trees in front of a red sky.

items.synopsis: The planet's average temperature hit 17.23 degrees Celsius on Thursday, surpassing the 17.18C record set on Tuesday and equalled on Wednesday.

title.children: For the fourth day in a row, Earth has broken or equalled its hottest average temperature record

image.altText: Elderly woman turns her eyes to the side to look at camera with bandana on head

items.synopsis: A trauma resource kit has been entirely developed by a group of senior Warlpiri women to help their community take the first steps towards healing.

title.children: 'We've got to keep them safe': Women work to break community's cycle of childhood trauma

image.altText: Jilkminggan community

items.synopsis: Police say a woman has died after being stabbed in the back in Jilkminggan community, south-east of Katherine.

title.children: Woman dies after being stabbed by man in remote NT community, police say

image.altText: A middle-aged woman with short hair and glasses looks at the camera

items.synopsis: The program funds community housing providers in Darwin and Alice Springs to sub-lease properties to people escaping domestic violence and at risk of homelessness.

title.children: DV is the leading cause of homelessness in the NT. This program aims to change that

image.altText: People watch on as flames and smoke billow from a burning car in a narrow laneway

items.synopsis: Police say a shooting at a Marrickville hair salon this afternoon was "brazen" and "targeted", after two men were rushed to hospital.

title.children: 'Brazen attack': Two men shot in Sydney barber shop were known to police

image.altText: Dad, son and dog all hugging in front of a police station, they're smiling

items.synopsis: The four-year-old Australian shepherd was reported missing after an alleged break-in at Southport earlier this week.

title.children: Bowie the blind dog reunited with family after being found safe and well 300km from Gold Coast home

image.altText: The view from inside a car travelling on a country highway on a gloomy day.

items.synopsis: Leading Senior Constable Bradley John Beecroft says he is "relieved with a just outcome". Charges were brought against him after he responded to an incident involving another police officer in 2021.

title.children: Victorian police officer clocked at 230kph cleared of dangerous driving charges

image.altText: A bland photo showing a close-up of a phone screen with Threads' listing in the Apple App Store displayed.

items.synopsis: The move ramps up the tensions between the social media giants since Threads debuting this week, targeting those opposed to changes Elon Musk has made to the platform since buying it last year.

title.children: Twitter threatens legal action over Meta's 'copycat' Threads app, as platform draws in millions

image.altText: A composite image of Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg

items.synopsis: With its simple black and white feed, the similarities between Threads and Twitter are obvious. But will it finally unseat Twitter, asks Lisa M. Given.

title.children: Meta's Threads app is the biggest threat to Twitter yet. Here's why

image.altText: An official measures radiation levels of a fish imported from Japan as they conduct a radioactivity check.

items.synopsis: A two-year review from the International Atomic Energy Agency says Japan's plan for the release will have a negligible environmental impact.

title.children: Japan's nuclear regulator approves release of Fukushima water

image.altText: This image provided by Eisai shows vials and packaging for their medication, Leqembi.

items.synopsis: US officials grant full approval to the closely watched Alzheimer's drug Leqembi, as Australia receives an application.

title.children: Promising Alzheimer's drug gets green light in US as Australia evaluates application

image.altText: Ross Fox wearing a dark business suit, sitting at a small with four energetic school students writing in their notepads.

items.synopsis: Universities will be given two years to overhaul their education degrees or risk losing their accreditation as part of a national bid to fix Australia's teacher shortage.

title.children: Universities will have to improve their teaching degrees or face consequences. The reactions have been mixed

image.altText: Jamie Kah smiles, in jockey outfit as she rides a horse at Flemington Racecourse.

items.synopsis: Racing authorities accuse Jamie Kah and two others of breaching the sport's rules over pictures showing them with a white powder.

title.children: Top jockey Jamie Kah charged by racing stewards over 'white powder' images

image.altText: The Robodebt royal commission report handed to the federal government

items.synopsis: Unnamed individuals will be referred for criminal and civil prosecution after a royal commission handed down its report into the unlawful Robodebt scheme today.

title.children: Commissioner brands Robodebt 'extraordinary saga' of 'venality, incompetence and cowardice'

image.altText: A close up picture of Aretha smiling

items.synopsis: Music superstar Aretha Franklin died without a formal will. An upcoming trial over two handwritten documents, including one found in couch cushions, could determine who gets her valuable estate.

title.children: Two handwritten wills could hold the key to Aretha Franklin's final wishes

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt kneels down beside a boy in a wheelchair

items.synopsis: When Kununurra automotive mechanic Mick Scott turned his hand to fixing a specialist wheelchair, he helped save a young boy's holiday in the process.

title.children: How this outback mechanic salvaged Cooper's Kimberley trip

image.altText: Manasseh Sogavare standing at an event outside.

items.synopsis: Solomon Islands' PM thanks Australia, leaves out China in annual speech while questioning 'LGBTQIA+ threat'.

title.children: Solomon Islands PM questions 'LGBTQI+ weaponisation' in speech that thanks Australia and ignores China

image.altText: David MacPhail outside Warrnambool Magistrates' Court in 2022.

items.synopsis: Judge John Smallwood told the court the ruling was made "as no jury, properly instructed" could find Senior Constable David MacPhail guilty.

title.children: Judge stops trial, acquits veteran police officer of assault

image.altText: A man handballs a football away.

items.synopsis: Magpies champion Scott Pendlebury claims the VFL/AFL disposal record, as the Pies see off the Bulldogs at Docklands.

title.children: Pendlebury claims VFL/AFL disposal record as Daicos stars at Docklands

image.altText: Raiders try

items.synopsis: The Raiders have mocked Jonny Bairstow with a try celebration, as they survived a scare from the Dragons.

title.children: Raiders poke fun at English cricketers with try celebration as they survive Dragons scare

image.altText: An artist impression of the James Webb Space Telescope.

items.synopsis: The CEERS 1019 black hole existed more than 570 million years after the Big Bang, but it's much smaller than its peers.

title.children: James Webb Space Telescope's latest find 'difficult to explain', says NASA

image.altText: Dog in a cages at a pound.

items.synopsis: The RSPCA's chief executive says the "fierce opposition" to an upgrade at its Katoomba animal shelter has been "staggering" and staff members have been abused on the streets of the Blue Mountains town.

title.children: 'Conspiracy theory' and abuse from hostile community behind animal shelter closure, RSPCA says

image.altText: Peter Dutton smiles during first press conference as Opposition Leader.

items.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton is ramping up calls for nuclear power in Australia, arguing reactors could be built on the sites of coal-fired power stations.

title.children: Peter Dutton opting for the nuclear option for Australia's energy future

image.altText: Police behind police tape and a firetruck.

items.synopsis: Italian emergency services say six people are dead and around 80 injured after a fire in a Milan retirement home.

title.children: Retirement home fire kills six people, injures 80 in Italy

image.altText: A man wearing a green and yellow shawl leans over a grave while holding a photo of his son.

items.synopsis: Baruch's only son was suddenly killed in military action. Now he's fighting for permission to use his son's sperm to create a grandchild.

title.children: Baruch is so desperate to be a grandparent, he is fighting for a child to be born with 'planned orphanhood'
